questions.text: Sugarbaker's technique is used in
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pseudomyxoma peritonei This rare condition occurs more frequently in women. The abdomen is filled with yellow jelly, large quantities of which are often encysted. The condition is associated with mucinous cystic tumors of the ovary & appendix. It is often painless and there is frequently no impairment of general health. Pseudomyxoma peritonei does not give rise to extraperitoneal metastases but causes symptoms & complications due to tumor milk. Although an abdomen distended with what seems to be fluid that cannot be made to shift should raise the possibility, the diagnosis is more often suggested by ultrasonography and CT scanning, or made at operation. At laparotomy , masses of jelly are scooped out. The appendix, if present, should be excised together with any ovarian More definitive treatment can be achieved by ‘complete cyto reduction’ (Sugarbaker technique) in which the right hemicolon, spleen, gall bladder, and greater and lesser omentum are excised, along with stripping of the peritoneum from the pelvis and diaphragm, stripping of the tumor from the surface of the liver (the uterus and ovaries are also removed in women). Intraoperative heated chemotherapy (using mitomycin C) follows and the whole procedure takes about 10 hours.

Highyeild:

Pseudomyxoma peritone i Pseudomyxoma peritone i is a condition where mucinous ascites fill the peritoneal cavity due to a ruptured appendiceal or ovarian adenocarcinoma. The most common site of primary cancer leading to pseudomyxoma peritonei is the appendix . The condition usually affects individuals aged 40-50 and occurs with equal frequency in men and women. Patients are often asymptomatic until late in the disease course and may present with abdominal pain and distention, and nonspecific complaints. Physical examination may reveal a new hernia, ascites, distended abdomen with non shifting dullness, and occasionally a palpable abdominal mass. A CT scan can help diagnose and evaluate the extent of the tumor. Preoperative colonoscopy can differentiate a mucinous neoplasm of the appendix from that arising from the colon. The diagnosis is often made during laparotomy, where the peritoneal cavity contains tenacious semisolid mucus and large, loculated cystic masses. Treatment involves cytoreduction , which is the resection of as much of the tumor as possible, followed by intraperitoneal hyperthermic chemotherapy (IPHC).

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Carcinomatosis peritonei is a condition in which cancer cells spread to the peritoneum, the membrane that lines the abdominal cavity, resulting in the formation of multiple tumors throughout the peritoneum. Option: C . Peritoneal inclusion cysts are benign cystic lesions that develop within the peritoneal cavity and are often associated with prior abdominal surgeries or pelvic inflammatory disease. Option: D . Peritoneal loose bodies are small, free-floating nodules of calcified tissue that can be found in the peritoneal cavity, often incidentally discovered during imaging studies.

Extraedge:

Operative management may include omentectomy, stripping of involved peritoneum, resection of involved organs, and appendectomy with right hemicolectomy. The survival rate for pseudomyxoma peritonei depends on the type of primary cancer, with adenomucinosis having the best survival rate ( 75% at 5 years ) and peritoneal mucinous carcinomatosis having the worst ( 14% at 5 years ).

questions.correct_answer: C. Derived from the diverticulum of the mesenteric border of the intestine
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Derived from the diverticulum of the mesenteric border of the intestine CHYLOLYMPHATIC CYST: Although all mesenteric cysts are rare, this is the most common variety, probably arising in congenitally misplaced lymphatic tissue that has no efferent communication with the lymphatic system (most frequently in the mesentery of the ileum). The thin wall of the cyst, which is composed of connective tissue lined by flat endothelium, is filled with clear lymph or, less frequently, with chyle, varying in consistency from watered milk to cream. Occasionally, the cyst attains a great size. More often unilocular than multilocular, a Chylolymphatic cyst is almost invariably solitary, although there is an extremely rare variety in which myriads of cysts are found in the various mesenteries of the abdomen. A chylolymphatic cyst has a blood supply that is independent from that of the adjacent intestine and, thus, enucleation is possible without the need of resection of the gut. ENTEROGENOUS CYST: These are believed to be derived either from a diverticulum of the mesenteric border of the intestine that has become sequestrated from the intestinal canal during embryonic life, or from a duplication of the intestine. An enterogenous cyst has a thicker wall than a chylolymphatic cyst and it is lined by a mucous membrane, which is sometimes ciliated. The content is mucinous and either colorless or yellowish brown as a result of past hemorrhage. The muscle in the wall of an enteric duplication cyst and the bowel with which it is in contact have a common blood supply; consequently, removal of the cyst always entails resection of the related portion of the intestine.

Highyeild:

Mesenteric cysts are typically seen in young adults, usually in the second decade of life, and more commonly in women. Types of mesenteric cysts: Chylolymphatic (MC), Simple (mesothelial), Enterogenous, Urogenital remnant, and Dermoid (teratomatous cyst). Clinical features of mesenteric cysts include painless abdominal swelling, recurrent attacks of abdominal pain, acute abdominal pain due to torsion, rupture, hemorrhage, or infection, and Tillaux triad. CT scan is the diagnostic modality of choice for mesenteric cysts, while ultrasound can also be helpful. Treatment options vary depending on the type of cyst, but enucleation is usually the treatment of choice for Chylolymphatic cysts, while resection and anastomosis are typically necessary for Enterogenous cysts. Aspiration alone is not recommended due to a high recurrence rate.

questions.text: The surgical option for single perforation due to typhoid is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primary closure Typhoid enteritis: Typhoid fever and uncomplicated typhoid enteritis are treated by antibiotic administration. If a patient presents with clinical symptoms and has been in an endemic area, broad-spectrum empirical antibiotics should be started immediately. Intestinal perforation through an ulcerated Peyer’s patch occurs in approximately 2% of cases. Typically, it is a single perforation in the terminal ileum, and simple closure of the perforation is the treatment of choice.

Highyeild:

Typhoid fever is a problem in developing countries with contaminated water and inadequate waste disposal, affecting millions and causing thousands of deaths annually. Children and young adults are most often affected, and improvements in sanitation have decreased its incidence in industrialized countries. The fever is caused by Salmonella typhi , which penetrates the small bowel mucosa and spreads systemically, leading to hyperplasia and ulceration of Peyer patches. Diagnosis is confirmed by isolating the organism from blood, bone marrow, and stool cultures , but other tests are available with varying success rates. Antibiotic therapy is the primary treatment, with prompt administration crucial to reducing the risk of complications and fatalities. Surgical intervention may be required for hemorrhage or perforation, but their incidence has reduced with antibiotic availability.

options.label: B
options.text: Steatorrhea, Myeloblastic anemia & deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins

options.label: D
options.text: C14 xylose or C14 cholylglycine breath tests are indirect test for bacterial overgrowth.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Surgery is not indicated Blind Loop Syndrome: Blind loop syndrome is a rare condition manifested by diarrhea, steatorrhea, megaloblastic anemia, weight loss, abdominal pain, and deficiencies of fat-soluble vitamins as well as neurologic disorders. The underlying cause of this syndrome is bacterial overgrowth in stagnant areas of the small bowel produced by stricture, stenosis, fistulas, or diverticula (e.g., jejunoileal or Meckel’s diverticulum). The syndrome can be confirmed by a series of laboratory investigations. Bacterial overgrowth can be diagnosed with cultures obtained through an intestinal tube or by indirect tests such as the 14C-xylose or 14C-cholylglycine breath tests. Excessive bacterial use of 14C substrate leads to an increase in 14C-CO2. After bacterial overgrowth and steatorrhea are confirmed, a Schilling test (57Co-labeled vitamin B12 absorption) may be performed, which should reveal a pattern of urinary excretion of vitamin B12 resembling that of pernicious anemia (a urinary loss of 0% to 6% of vitamin B12 compared with the normal of 7% to 25%). In patients with blind loop syndrome, vitamin B12 excretion is not altered by the addition of intrinsic factor, but a course of a broad-spectrum antibiotic (e.g., tetracycline) should return vitamin B12 absorption to normal. Treatment of patients with blind loop syndrome includes parenteral vitamin B12 therapy and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Tetracyclines have been the mainstay of treatment, but studies have shown that rifaximin and metronidazole demonstrate less resistance and are also effective. For most patients, a single course of therapy (7 to 10 days) is sufficient, and the patient may remain symptom-free for months. Prokinetic agents have been used without real success. Surgical correction of the condition causing stagnation and blind loop syndrome produces a permanent cure and is indicated for patients who require multiple rounds of antibiotics or are receiving continuous therapy.

Highyeild:

Blind loop syndrome is caused by bacterial overgrowth in stagnant areas of the small bowel due to stricture, stenosis, fistulas, or diverticula. Symptoms include diarrhea, steatorrhea, megaloblastic anemia, weight loss, abdominal pain, deficiencies of fat-soluble vitamins, and neurologic disorders. Bacterial overgrowth can be diagnosed through cultures obtained by an intestinal tube or indirect tests such as 14C-xylose or 14C-cholylglycine breath tests. The Schilling test (57Co-labeled vitamin B12 absorption) may be performed to confirm vitamin B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia.

Extraedge:

Treatment includes parenteral vitamin B12 therapy and broad-spectrum antibiotics, such as tetracycline, rifaximin, or metronidazole. Surgical correction of the underlying cause is indicated for patients requiring multiple rounds of antibiotics or continuous therapy.

questions.text: The elective surgical option for ulcerative colitis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above In the elective setting, four operations are available – all of these can be successfully performed laparoscopically in experienced hands: Subtotal colectomy and ileostomy (as in an emergency); Proctocolectomy and permanent end ileostomy; Restorative proctocolectomy with ileoanal pouch; Subtotal colectomy and ileorectal anastomosis. Segmental resections are not recommended as even when the right side is not obviously involved there is a high recurrence rate in the remaining colon. Subtotal colectomy with ileostomy is performed electively for a frail patient, a patient who cannot be weaned from steroids, and when there is doubt as to whether the colitis may represent CD. A pouch, a completion proctectomy, and even an ileorectal anastomosis can be considered at a future date.

Highyeild:

Laparoscopic procedures are available for elective surgery. The following operations can be performed laparoscopically in experienced hands: Subtotal colectomy and ileostomy (as in an urgent colectomy) Proctocolectomy and permanent end-ileostomy Restorative proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA) Subtotal colectomy and ileorectal anastomosis Segmental colectomy (for Crohn's colitis only) Segmental resections are not recommended for UC due to a high recurrence rate. Subtotal colectomy with ileostomy is performed electively in frail patients, patients who cannot be weaned from steroids, and when there is doubt about the underlying diagnosis. Restorative surgery or completion proctectomy can be considered at a later date. Complications of CD, such as fibrotic strictures and enteric fistulae, are common indications for elective surgery. Patients who have previously undergone emergency resection and stoma formation will require follow-up for counseling about the restoration of bowel continuity.

questions.text: The complication of diverticular disease is/are:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Complications of diverticular disease Diverticulitis Abscess Peritonitis Intestinal obstruction Hemorrhage Fistula formation

Highyeild:

Diverticula are abnormal hollow outpouchings in the gastrointestinal tract. They can be classified as congenital or acquired depending on the presence of the muscularis layer in the diverticulum. The majority of patients with diverticulosis do not experience symptoms, but 10-30% may develop complications. Complications of diverticular disease include diverticulitis, abscess, peritonitis, intestinal obstruction, hemorrhage, and fistula formation. The degree of infection significantly impacts the outcome of acute diverticulitis, with patients with inflammatory masses having lower mortality than those with perforation. Classifications, such as the Hinchey classification , have been developed to better understand complicated diverticulitis.

questions.text: Identify the sign shown in a neonatal abdominal X-ray:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Double bubble sign Intestinal atresia: Duodenal atresia may take the form of a membrane or the proximal and distal duodenum may be completely separated. The prenatal ultrasound finds a ‘double bubble’ in the fetal abdomen with poly-hydramnios. There is an association with Down syndrome. Postnatally, there is bilious vomiting if the atresia is distal to the ampulla. A plain abdominal X-ray also shows the double bubble. Repair is by open duodenoduodenostomy. Occasionally, there is a duodenal membrane with a modest central perforation, which may delay symptoms until later childhood. Jejunal/ileal atresia vary from an obstructing membrane to widely separated blind-ended bowel ends associated with a mesenteric defect. Small bowel atresia’s may be single or multiple and are probably secondary to a prenatal vascular or mechanical insult causing sterile infarction of a segment of the gut. They present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth. The proximal bowel is often extremely dilated and needs to be tapered prior to anastomosis to the distal bowel.

Highyeild:

Duodenal atresia is a congenital anomaly that results from the failure of vacuolization of the duodenum during its solid cord stage. There are three anatomic variants of duodenal atresia, which are Type I (mucosal web with the intact muscular wall), Type II (two ends separated by a fibrous cord), and Type III (complete separation with a gap within the duodenum) .

Extraedge:

Duodenal atresia is associated with various anomalies such as prematurity, Down syndrome, polyhydramnios, malrotation, annular pancreas, biliary atresia, cardiac, renal, esophageal, and anorectal anomalies.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of the tube shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pneumothorax The image shows a Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube. Gastrostomy: The placement of a tube through the abdominal wall directly into the stomach is termed ‘gastrostomy ’. Historically, these were created surgically at the time of laparotomy. Today, the majority are performed by percutaneous insertion under endoscopic control using local anesthesia, known as PEG(percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy) tubes. Two methods of PEG are commonly used. The first is called the ‘direct-stab’ technique in which the endoscope is passed and the stomach is filled with air. The endoscopist then watches a cannula entering the stomach having been inserted directly through the anterior abdominal wall. A guidewire is then passed through the cannula into the stomach. A gastrostomy tube (commercially available) may then be introduced into the stomach through a ‘peel away’ sheath. The alternative technique is the transoral or push-through technique, whereby a guidewire or suture is brought out of the stomach by the endoscope after transabdominal percutaneous insertion and is either attached to a gastrostomy tube or the tube is pushed over a guidewire. The abdominal end of the wire is then pulled, advancing the gastrostomy tube through the esophagus and into the stomach. Continued pulling abuts it up against the abdominal wall. If patients require enteral nutrition for prolonged periods (4–6 weeks), then PEG is preferable to an indwelling nasogastric tube; this minimizes the traumatic complications related to indwelling tubes. PEG does have procedure-specific complications, although these are uncommon.

Highyeild:

Gastrostomy tubes are used for longer-term feeding and have physical, psychological, and lifestyle implications. There are three types of gastrostomy insertion : percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy ( PEG ), radiologically inserted gastrostomy ( RIG ), and surgical . PEG is inserted through the abdomen and stomach under endoscopic vision, avoiding surgery and general anesthesia. RIG is an option for patients who cannot have PEG and involves inserting a cannula under radiographic guidance. Surgical gastrostomy may be necessary for patients with distorted intra-abdominal anatomy, usually from previous surgery.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: B, C & D. Necrotising fasciitis and intra-abdominal wall abscesses have been recorded. Sepsis around the PEG site is more common and may necessitate systemic antibiotics or repositioning. A persistent gastric fistula can occur on the removal of a PEG if it has been in place for prolonged periods and epithelialization of the tract has occurred. This necessitates surgical closure. Fine-bore tube insertion: The patient should be semi-recumbent. The introducer wire is lubricated and inserted into the fine-bore tube. The tube is passed through the nose and into the stomach via the nasopharynx and esophagus. The wire is withdrawn and the tube is taped to the patient. There is a small risk of malposition into a bronchus or of causing pneumothorax. The position of the tube should be checked using plain abdominal radiography. A fine-bore feeding tube with its guidewire.

Extraedge:

Complications of gastrostomy include perforation, bleeding, peritonitis, localized sepsis, tube blockage, and displacement. Some gastrostomy devices can fit jejunal extensions, allowing the venting of stomach contents and simultaneous delivery of nutrients into the jejunum.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct diagnosis from the CT image shown below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Splenic pseudocyst. Image showing a Computed tomography scan of a large pseudocyst involving the spleen . There is the displacement of the stomach medially, and a trace of ascitic fluid is present above the liver. Non-parasitic splenic cysts are rare. Splenic cysts are classified as primary cysts (true) or pseudocysts (secondary) on the basis of the presence or absence of lining epithelium. True cysts form from embryonal rests and include dermoid and mesenchymal inclusion cysts. True cysts of the spleen are very rare and are frequently classified as cystic haemangiomas, cystic lymphangiomas, and epidermoid and dermoid cysts . Epidermoid cysts are thought to be of congenital origin and represent 10% of splenic cysts. They are lined by flattened squamous epithelium and are more frequent in children and young patients. Splenectomy or partial splenectomy is usually considered for cysts larger than 5 cm in diameter. These should be differentiated from false or secondary cysts that may result from trauma and contain serous or hemorrhagic fluid. The walls of such degenerative cysts may be calcified and therefore resemble the radiological appearances of a hydatid cyst. The spleen is also a common site for pseudocyst development following a severe attack of pancreatitis. Pseudocysts can easily be diagnosed on scanning, and intervention is normally required for symptomatic lesions that persist following a period of observation.

questions.text: The following pattern in radiography is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intestinal obstruction Radiograph shows fluid levels with gas above; ‘ stepladder pattern ’. Ileal obstruction by adhesions; patient erect. Erect abdominal films are no longer routinely obtained and the radiological diagnosis is based on a supine abdominal film. An erect film may subsequently be requested when further doubt exists. When distended with gas, the jejunum, ileum, caecum, and remaining colon have a characteristic appearance in adults and older children that allows them to be distinguished radiologically. In intestinal obstruction, fluid levels appear later than gas shadows as it takes time for gas and fluid to separate. These are most prominent on an erect film. In adults, two in constant fluid levels – one at the duodenal cap and the other in the terminal ileum – may be regarded as normal. In infants (less than 1-year-old), a few fluid levels in the small bowel may be physiological. In this age group, it is difficult to distinguish large from small bowel in the presence of obstruction, because the characteristic features seen in adults are not present or are unreliable.

questions.text: Unilateral claudication in the thigh and calf and sometimes the buttock, Bruit of the iliac region, and Unilateral absence of femoral and distal pulses are clinical features of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Iliac obstruction Relationship of clinical findings to the site of disease: Aortoiliac obstruction: Claudication in buttocks, thighs, and calves Femoral and distal pulses absent in both limbs Impotence (Leriche) Bruit over the aortoiliac region Iliac obstruction: Unilateral claudication in the thigh and calf and sometimes the buttock Unilateral absence of femoral and distal pulses Bruit over the iliac region Femoropopliteal obstruction: Unilateral claudication in the calf Femoral pulse palpable with absent unilateral distal pulses Distal obstruction: Femoral and popliteal pulses palpable Ankle pulses absent Claudication in calf and foot.

Highyeild:

Iliac obstruction refers to the narrowing or blockage of the iliac arteries , which are located in the pelvis and supply blood to the lower limbs. Iliac obstruction can cause unilateral claudication, which is pain or cramping in the thigh and calf muscles that occurs during physical activity and improves with rest. The severity of symptoms depends on the degree of blockage and the extent of collateral circulation. In some cases, the iliac obstruction may be asymptomatic. A bruit , which is an abnormal sound heard with a stethoscope , may be detected over the iliac region. The absence of femoral and distal pulses unilaterally is a common finding in patients with iliac obstruction.

Extraedge:

Iliac obstruction can be caused by atherosclerosis, which are the buildup of plaque inside the arteries, or by other conditions such as thrombosis or embolism. Treatment options for iliac obstruction include lifestyle modifications, medication, angioplasty with or without stenting, and surgical procedures such as bypass grafting or endarterectomy. Prompt diagnosis and treatment of iliac obstruction is important to prevent complications such as limb ischemia, gangrene, and amputation.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of passing large amounts of dark red blood from his rectum for 2 days. His parents noticed that he has also had several episodes of dark stools over the past 3 weeks. The parents report that their child has been sleeping more and has been more pale than usual over the past 24 hours. The boy's appetite has been normal and he has not been vomiting His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 38/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a small amount of dark red blood in the diaper. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Technetium 99m pertechnetate scan The young boy has Meckel's diverticulum . Technetium-99m pertechnetate scan is the ideal diagnostic test when there is a high suspicion for Meckel diverticulum in children, as is the case in this 18-month-old boy presenting with gastrointestinal bleeding. This scan uses a radioactive tracer that has a high affinity for gastric mucosa and is, therefore, able to identify Meckel diverticulum with high sensitivity and specificity. Ectopic gastric mucosa can secrete gastric acid within the diverticulum, possibly resulting in ileal ulceration and subsequent bleeding.

Highyeild:

Meckel's Diverticulum Meckel's Diverticulum is the most commonly encountered congenital anomaly of the small intestine and occurs in 2% of the population. The "Rule of Two" in Meckel's Diverticulum refers to its 2% prevalence, 2-inch length, location 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve, and the fact that half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age. Meckel's Diverticulum is a true diverticulum as it has all three layers of the intestine and is located on the antimesenteric border of the ileum 45 to 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve. Meckel's Diverticulum results from incomplete closure of the omphalomesenteric or vitellointestinal duct and is characterized by the presence of heterotopic tissue, with gastric mucosa being the most common (50%), followed by pancreatic mucosa (5%) and colonic mucosa (rarely). The most common clinical presentation of Meckel's Diverticulum is gastrointestinal bleeding (25-50% ), which is manifested as painless bright red blood from the rectum , with intermittent episodes persisting without treatment. Meckel's Diverticulum can also cause intestinal obstruction (31%), diverticulitis (10-20%), perforation, and peritonitis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option:A . Plain abdominal x-rays can be used in the diagnoses of conditions that involve bowel distention or perforation, such as necrotizing enterocolitis or congenital abnormalities of the gastrointestinal tract in children (e.g., duodenal atresia). This boy does not present with abdominal distention or tenderness, which would be expected in these conditions. Additionally, he is 18 months old and therefore past the window in which these conditions would manifest. His findings are more consistent with a Meckel diverticulum that would not be seen on a plain abdominal X-ray. Option: C . Rectal suction biopsy is used for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease. This disease would manifest in neonates and would present with vomiting, constipation, and abdominal distention (none of which is present in this patient). A rectal suction biopsy would not be useful in the diagnosis of Meckel diverticulum, which is usually located in the distal ileum rather than the rectum. Option: D . A water-soluble contrast enema may be performed for the workup of abdominal pain and/or constipation, as it may reveal conditions such as Hirschsprung disease, meconium plug, or distal bowel obstruction/atresia. This patient does not present with abdominal pain or constipation. His symptoms are highly suggestive of a Meckel diverticulum that would not be visible in a water-soluble contrast enema study.

Extraedge:

Scintigraphy with sodium 99mTc-pertechnetate is the most accurate diagnostic test in children, while barium studies should be performed in adults with normal nuclear medicine findings. Treatment of symptomatic Meckel's Diverticulum involves diverticulectomy or resection of the segment of ileum bearing the diverticulum, while asymptomatic diverticula found in children during laparotomy should be resected .

questions.text: A previously healthy 11-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of abdominal pain and vomiting. His mother states that over the past 6 hours, he has been having intermittent episodes of inconsolable crying, during which he “grabs his abdomen and draws up his legs.” These episodes have been accompanied by non bloody, non bilious vomiting and reddish, mucoid bowel movements. He appears sleepy. He cries when his abdomen is palpated. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 12,000/mm3. Abdominal ultrasonography is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Air enema Air enema is the treatment of choice for intussusception . It creates pressure within the intestine and pushes the bowel back into its normal position. Hydrostatic enema is a viable alternative (the mechanism is the same, only normal saline is used instead of air). After the procedure, the patient should be monitored for 24 hours, as intussusception tends to recur during that time frame.

He had two similar episodes within the past 6 months. Abdominal examination shows periumbilical tenderness with no masses palpated. Transverse abdominal ultrasound shows concentric rings of the bowel. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.2 g/dL. Which of the following is the most common underlying cause of this patient's condition?

Solution:

A pathological lead point should always be suspected in children older than 5 years of age who present with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, especially if symptoms occur within 6 months of the last episode . questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of recurrent episodes of vomiting for 1 day. He has had over 15 episodes of bilious vomiting. During this period he has had cramping abdominal pain but has not had a bowel movement or passed flatus. He does not have a fever or diarrhea. He was diagnosed with Crohn’s disease at the age of 28 years which has been well controlled with oral mesalamine. He underwent a partial small bowel resection before. His other medications include vitamin B12, folic acid, loperamide, ferrous sulfate, and vitamin D3. He appears uncomfortable and his lips are parched. His temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F), his pulse is 103/min, and his blood pressure is 104/70 mm Hg. The abdomen is distended, tympanitic, and tender to palpation over the periumbilical area and the right lower quadrant. Rectal examination is unremarkable. A CT scan of the abdomen shows multiple dilated loops of the small bowel with a transition zone in the mid to distal ileum. After 24 hours of conservative management with IV fluid resuscitation, nasogastric bowel decompression, promethazine, and analgesia, his condition does not improve and a laparotomy is scheduled. During the laparotomy, two discrete strictures are noted in the mid-ileum, around 20 cm apart. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Small bowel resection and primary anastomosis

options.label: D
options.text: Abdominal closure and start of palliative care

questions.explanation:
Solution:

His history of Crohn’s disease also puts him at risk of developing adhesions and fistulas after surgery. Therefore, any surgical procedures to treat his small bowel obstruction should be kept as restrictive as possible. The best option is a bowel-sparing technique like strictureplasty.

Highyeild:

Strictureplasty is a local widening procedure used to treat areas of Crohn's disease (CD ) that are narrowed due to fibrostenotic disease. It helps to avoid small bowel resection and is an important bowel-sparing technique. Strictureplasty is particularly useful when there is little or no active inflammation in the involved segment. It is contraindicated in the presence of phlegmon , Crohn's associated cancer, or hemorrhage due to mucosal ulceration. Frozen biopsy carried out intraoperatively may allow a strictureplasty to take place rather than resection if there is any concern about malignancy at the site of a stricture. The Heineke-Mikulicz technique of an antimesenteric longitudinal incision that is closed transversely is the most common technique used for strictureplasty. A Finney antimesenteric side-to-side anastomosis is used to treat long segments of stenosis when preservation of bowel length is important. Multiple strictureplasties can be performed, and strictureplasty can be combined with resection. Complete excision of macroscopically diseased mesentery may reduce the incidence of recurrence following resection, as may anastomotic techniques that ensure that an anastomosis is fashioned on the antimesenteric aspect of the bowel ( Kono - S procedure).

Causes and Risk Factors: tuberculosis is responsible for all cases of GI tuberculosis. bovis has largely been eliminated by public health measures. Intestinal tuberculosis is more common in poor socioeconomic status. Ingestion of contaminated food may cause primary tuberculosis. Tuberculous bacilli can be ingested through swallowed sputum. Primary intestinal tuberculosis can lead to secondary intestinal tuberculosis. The earliest intestinal lesions are found in the submucosa, while the overlying mucosa is normal. The most common site of involvement is the terminal ileum and ileocecal junction. Other affected regions, in decreasing frequency, include the colon, jejunum, rectum, anal canal, duodenum, stomach, and esophagus. The site of predilection is dictated by the abundance of lymphoid tissue, rate of absorption of intestinal contents, prolonged stasis, and digestive activity of intestinal contents. Clinical Features: Initial symptoms are vague and non-specific. As the disease progresses, individuals may develop fever, night sweats, malaise, weakness, anorexia, and weight loss. The most common symptom of GI tuberculosis is abdominal pain. Diarrhea is another common symptom. Abdominal distention suggests the presence of ascites or subacute intestinal obstruction. Diagnosis: The most common laboratory abnormality is a raised ESR. Ascitic fluid may show lymphocytosis, high protein content, SAAG <1.1, and raised adenosine deaminase. Radiological imaging, such as ultrasound and CT scans, can help diagnose GI tuberculosis. Barium studies can also help diagnose GI tuberculosis, with characteristic features such as the Fleishner or umbrella sign, string sign, Sterlein sign, and napkin ring stenosis. Treatment: The treatment of GI tuberculosis is ATT (anti-tuberculosis treatment) . Fever, malaise, and weight loss can subside in a few weeks. The majority of patients with symptoms of subacute intestinal obstruction and evidence of intestinal strictures show complete resolution of the radiological abnormality. Surgery may be necessary for intestinal obstruction secondary to stricture, free perforation, severe GI hemorrhage, intra-abdominal abscess, internal or external fistula.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ectopic Gastric mucosa on technetium 99m pertechnetate scan Technetium-99 m pertechnetate scan showing ectopic gastric mucosa in the small bowel is diagnostic of Meckel diverticulum in children. Meckel diverticulum is a true diverticulum that may contain ectopic gastric mucosa and/or pancreatic tissue. Acid secretion by gastric mucosa within the diverticulum results in ileal ulceration and subsequent bleeding. Consequently, chronic blood loss can lead to iron deficiency anemia, and thus a low MCV, as seen in this patient.

Highyeild:

Meckel's Diverticulum Meckel's Diverticulum is the most commonly encountered congenital anomaly of the small intestine and occurs in 2% of the population. The "Rule of Two" in Meckel's Diverticulum refers to its 2% prevalence, 2-inch length, location 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve, and the fact that half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age. Meckel's Diverticulum is a true diverticulum as it has all three layers of the intestine and is located on the antimesenteric border of the ileum 45 to 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve. Meckel's Diverticulum results from incomplete closure of the omphalomesenteric or vitellointestinal duct and is characterized by the presence of heterotopic tissue, with gastric mucosa being the most common (50%), followed by pancreatic mucosa (5%) and colonic mucosa (rarely). The most common clinical presentation of Meckel's Diverticulum is gastrointestinal bleeding (25-50% ), which is manifested as painless bright red blood from the rectum , with intermittent episodes persisting without treatment. Meckel's Diverticulum can also cause intestinal obstruction (31%), diverticulitis (10-20%), perforation, and peritonitis.

This disease can manifest with lower gastrointestinal bleeding and subsequent microcytic anemia, as seen in this patient. However, UC is also associated with abdominal pain, tenesmus, failure to thrive, and extraintestinal manifestations (e.g., uveitis, arthritis, erythema nodosum). Furthermore, the peak incidence of UC is 15–35 years; therefore, it is unlikely in this 15-month-old patient.

Scintigraphy with sodium 99mTc-pertechnetate is the most accurate diagnostic test in children, while barium studies should be performed in adults with normal nuclear medicine findings. Treatment of symptomatic Meckel's Diverticulum involves diverticulectomy or resection of the segment of ileum bearing the diverticulum, while asymptomatic diverticula found in children during laparotomy should be resected .
